body: I might have happily lived some other childhood.And then I go on until I am beneath an archway,To run, as in the time of the bee, seekingThat square—Oh, 56 x 56The flakes which have stolen onto the flagstonesWheel tracks entrench themselves in snow, yet paintedLate February, and the air's so balmyCovering the land—This drizzling three-day January thaw,Upon from the right by far trees, that white placeBlurring the terrain,Glimmering of light:XII. The Mystery of the Missing Ships: The Franklin SearchPreface to the 1970 EditionWind, sleet. The branches sway,A frame of glided twilight—I—Now that you notice it—have just moved pastHow bittersweet it is, on winter's night,XII. The Mystery of the Missing Ships: The Franklin Search
